I see a lot of comments wondering about why we use the elevators instead of stairs in-case of emergencies. Reason is that the experiments are 100m underground, and climbing the stairs up for 100m is demanding even for a fit person. Therefore the lifts (and lift entrances) are positively pressurized and powered by a separated power system with multiple backups to ensure function and safety even in the most extreme emergencies. Also the lifts are specially made for CERN and ensured to function even under strong magnetic fields that are present when the detectors are "switched on".

5:55 It seems to me that the point of this section is to show that quantum fields are more fundamental than the particles that emerge from them. But, I don't think it's quite accurate to say that a particle can "exist or not" based on the motion of the observer. This really depends on the excitation energy of the field. In particular, this can seem to contradict the fact that the equations in Quantum Field Theory are constructed in such that they are Lorentz covariant (i.e. any equation that holds in a given inertial frame and can be written down in terms of Lorentz covariant terms will hold in all inertial frames). But the properties of a particle will certainly change under relative motion (think of redshift as an example, where the frequency of the photon - and hence its momentum - will depend on the relative motion wrt the observer).

As much as I like your enthusiasm, I think that you should also mention that the LHC disappointed in that way, that it until now did not found any experimental results for physics beyond the standard model. We know of some problems with the standard model (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unsolved_problems_in_physics#High-energy_physics/particle_physics) but the LHC did not give us any clue where to search for physics beyond the standard model. SUSY physicists (and therefore string theoreticians as well) had high hopes for the discovery of the lightest supersymmetric partner particle, but the LHC found nothing. LHCb is trying to find hints why gravity is so weak, compared to the other forces, but found nothing. Some physicist go that far to call that a "crisis in physics". The LHC promised to find the Higgs and it did, but then it seemed to fall silent. So some theoretical physicist continue to "float" in experimental unaccessible regions, producing wilder and wilder hyothesises and losing contact to experimental physics. Some ask if these "wild hypothesises" are still science at all -- and the LHC unfortunately failed to ground these theoreticians and rejoin the physics community.

There are two types of hadrons - baryons and mesons. Mesons are made of two quarks and baryons are the larger hadrons that have 3 quarks. It is these larger hadrons that are smashed in the large hadron collider. The reason we don't have a small hadron collider is that the small hadrons, or mesons, are made of one quark and an anti-quark and they turn into photons very quickly. So we only have large hadrons to smash. Why didn't they just name it the baryon collider? I never trust atoms because they make up everything.
